27.verse: The Authority of Jesus Is Questioned - Once more they went into Jerusalem. As Jesus was walking in the Temple he was approached by the chief priests, the legal experts and the elders.

28.verse: ‘By what right do you do these things?’ they asked. ‘Who gave you the right to do them?’

29.verse: ‘I have one question for you, too,’ replied Jesus, ‘and if you tell me the answer I shall tell you by what right I do these things.

30.verse: Was the baptism of John from heaven, or was it a human invention? What’s your answer?’

31.verse: ‘Well now,’ they muttered to each other, ‘if we say it was from heaven, he will say, “Then why didn’t you believe him?”

32.verse: But if we say it was a human invention . . .’ They were afraid of the crowd, because everyone regarded John as a prophet.

33.verse: ‘We don’t know,’ they said to Jesus. ‘Nor will I tell you’, replied Jesus, ‘by what right I do these things.’

1.verse: The Parable of the Tenants - Jesus began to speak to them with parables. ‘Once upon a time,’ he began, ‘there was a man who planted a vineyard. He built a fence around it, dug out a wine-press, built a watchtower, and then let it out to tenant farmers. He himself went abroad.

2.verse: When the time came he sent a slave to the farmers to collect from them his portion of the vineyard’s produce.

3.verse: They seized him, beat him and sent him away empty-handed.

4.verse: ‘So again he sent another slave to them. This one they beat about the head, and treated shamefully.

5.verse: He sent another, and they killed him. He sent several more; they beat some and killed others.

6.verse: ‘He had one more to send: his beloved son. He sent him to them last of all, thinking “They will respect my son”.

7.verse: ‘But the tenant farmers said to themselves, “This is the heir! Come on – let’s kill him, and we’ll get the inheritance!”

8.verse: So they seized him and killed him, and threw him out of the vineyard.

9.verse: ‘So what will the vineyard owner do? He will come and destroy those tenants, and give the vineyard to others.

10.verse: Or haven’t you read the scripture which says, There is the stone the builders refused; now it’s in place at the top of the corner.

11.verse: This happened the way the Lord planned it; we were astonished to see it.’

12.verse: They tried to find a way of arresting him, because they realized he had directed the parable against them. But they were afraid of the crowd. They left him and went away.

13.verse: On Paying Taxes to Caesar - They sent some Pharisees to Jesus, and some Herodians, to try to trick him into saying the wrong thing.

14.verse: ‘Teacher,’ they said, ‘we know you are a man of integrity; you don’t regard anybody as special. You don’t bother about the outward show people put up; you teach God’s way truly. ‘Well then: is it lawful to give tribute to Caesar or not? Should we pay it, or shouldn’t we?’

15.verse: He knew the game they were playing. ‘Why are you trying to trap me?’ he said. ‘Bring me a tribute-coin; let me look at it.’

16.verse: They brought one to him. ‘This image,’ he asked, ‘whose is it? And whose is this superscription?’ ‘Caesar’s,’ they replied.

17.verse: ‘Well then,’ said Jesus, ‘give Caesar back what belongs to Caesar – and give God back what belongs to God!’ They were astonished at him.

18.verse: Marriage and the Resurrection - Some Sadducees approached Jesus (Sadducees, by the way, deny the resurrection).

19.verse: ‘Teacher,’ they said, ‘Moses wrote for us that “If a man’s brother dies, and leaves a wife but no child, the brother should take the wife and raise up descendents for his brother.”

20.verse: Well now: there were once seven brothers. The first married a wife, and died without children.

21.verse: The second married the widow, and died without children. The third did so as well,

22.verse: and so did all seven, still without leaving children. Finally the woman died too.

23.verse: So: when they rise again in the resurrection, whose wife will she be? All seven had her, after all.’

24.verse: ‘Where you’re going wrong’, replied Jesus, ‘is that you don’t know the scriptures, or God’s power.

25.verse: When people rise from the dead, they don’t marry, nor do people give them in marriage. They are like angels in heaven.

26.verse: ‘However, to show that the dead are indeed to be raised, surely you’ve read in the book of Moses, in the passage about the bush, what God says to Moses? “I am Abraham’s God, Isaac’s God and Jacob’s God”?

27.verse: He isn’t the God of the dead, but of the living. You are completely mistaken.’

28.verse: The Most Important Commandment - One of the legal experts came up, and overheard the discussion. Realizing that Jesus had given a splendid answer, he put a question of his own. ‘Which commandment’, he asked, ‘is the first one of all?’

29.verse: ‘The first one’, replied Jesus, ‘is this: “Listen, Israel: the Lord your God, the Lord is one;

30.verse: and you shall love the Lord your God with all your heart, and with all your soul, and with all your understanding, and with all your strength.”

31.verse: And this is the second one: “You shall love your neighbour as yourself.” No other commandment is greater than these ones.’

32.verse: ‘Well said, Teacher,’ answered the lawyer. ‘You are right in saying that “he is one and there is no other beside him”,

33.verse: and that “to love him with all the heart, and with all the intelligence, and with all the strength” and “to love one’s neighbour as oneself” is worth far more than all burnt offerings and sacrifices.’

34.verse: Jesus saw that his answer came out of deep understanding. ‘You are not far from God’s kingdom,’ he said to him. After that, nobody dared put any more questions to him.

35.verse: David’s Son and the Widow’s Mite - By way of response to it all, Jesus began to teach in the Temple. ‘Why do the experts say’, he asked, ‘that the Messiah is the son of David?

36.verse: David himself, inspired by the holy spirit, said: The Lord said to my Lord: sit at my right hand, until I place your enemies right underneath your feet.

37.verse: ‘David himself calls him “Lord”; how then can he be his son?’ The whole crowd listened to him with delight.

38.verse: During his teaching, he said, ‘Beware of the lawyers! They like to walk about in long robes, and to be greeted in the market-places.

39.verse: They take the chief seats in the synagogue, and the best places at dinner parties.

40.verse: They devour the property of widows, and make long prayers without meaning them. They will receive all the more condemnation.’

41.verse: As he sat opposite the Temple treasury, he watched the crowd putting money into the almsboxes. Lots of rich people put in substantial amounts.

42.verse: Then there came a single poor widow, who put in two tiny coins, together worth a single penny.

43.verse: Jesus called his disciples. ‘I’m telling you the truth,’ he said. ‘This poor widow just put more into the treasury than everybody else.

44.verse: You see, all the others were contributing out of their wealth; but she put in everything she had, out of her poverty. It was her whole livelihood.’

1.verse: Signs of the End - As they were going out of the Temple, one of Jesus’ disciples said to him, ‘Teacher! Look at these huge stones, and these huge buildings!’

2.verse: ‘You see these enormous buildings?’ said Jesus. ‘There will not be one single stone left on top of another. They will all be torn down.’

3.verse: Peter, James, John and Andrew approached him privately as he was sitting on the Mount of Olives opposite the Temple.

4.verse: ‘Tell us,’ they asked. ‘When will these things happen? What will be the sign that these things are about to be completed?’

5.verse: ‘Take care that nobody deceives you,’ Jesus began to say to them.

6.verse: ‘Plenty of people will come in my name, saying “I’m the one!”, and they will lead plenty astray.

7.verse: But whenever you hear about wars, and rumours about wars, don’t be disturbed. These things have to happen, but it doesn’t mean the end is here.

8.verse: One nation will rise up against another; one kingdom will rise up against another. There will be earthquakes from place to place, and famines too. These are the first pains of childbirth.

9.verse: ‘But watch out for yourselves. They will hand you over to courts, they will beat you in synagogues; you will stand before rulers and kings because of me, as a witness against them.

10.verse: And the message of the kingdom must first be announced to all the nations.

11.verse: And when they put you on trial and hand you over, don’t work out beforehand what you are going to say, but say whatever is given you at that moment. It won’t be you speaking, you see, but the holy spirit.

12.verse: ‘One brother will hand over another to death. Fathers will hand over children. Children will rebel against parents and have them put to death.

13.verse: And you will be hated by everyone because of my name. But the one who is patient through to the end – that one will be saved.’

14.verse: Further Signs of the End - ‘However,’ Jesus continued, ‘when you see “the desolating abomination” set up where it ought not to be’ (let the reader understand) ‘then those who are in Judaea should run away to the mountains.

15.verse: If you’re on the housetop, don’t go down, and don’t go in to get anything from the house.

16.verse: If you’re out in the countryside, don’t turn back again to pick up your cloak.

17.verse: ‘It will be a terrible time for pregnant and nursing mothers.

18.verse: Pray that it won’t happen in winter.

19.verse: Yes, those days will bring trouble like nothing that’s ever happened from the beginning of creation, which God created, until now, or ever will again.

20.verse: In fact, if the Lord had not shortened the days, no one would be rescued. But for the sake of his chosen ones, those whom he appointed, he shortened the days.

21.verse: ‘So at that time, if someone says to you, “Look – here is the Messiah!” or, “Look – there he is!”, don’t believe them;

22.verse: because false messiahs and false prophets will arise, and will perform signs and portents to lead astray even God’s chosen ones, if that were possible.

23.verse: But you must be on your guard. I’ve told you everything ahead of time.

24.verse: ‘But in those days, after that suffering, The sun will be dark as night and the moon will not give its light;

25.verse: the stars will fall from heaven and the powers in heaven will shake.

26.verse: ‘Then they will see “the son of man coming on clouds with great power and glory”.

27.verse: And then he will dispatch his messengers, and will gather in his chosen ones from the four winds, from the ends of earth to the ends of heaven.’

28.verse: Watching for the Son of Man - ‘Learn this lesson from the fig tree. When its branch becomes soft and sprouts leaves, you know that summer is near.

29.verse: In the same way, when you see these things happen, you should know that it is near, right at the gates.

30.verse: I’m telling you the truth: this generation won’t disappear until all of this has happened.

31.verse: Heaven and earth will disappear, but my words won’t disappear.

32.verse: ‘No one knows, though, the day or the hour. The angels in heaven don’t know it; nor does the son; only the father.

33.verse: ‘Keep watch, stay awake. You don’t know when the moment will arrive.

34.verse: It’s like a man who goes away from home: he leaves his house, giving each of his slaves authority for their own tasks; and he commands the doorkeeper to keep watch.

35.verse: Keep watch, then, because you don’t know when the master of the house is going to come. It might be at evening, or at midnight, or at cockcrow, or in the morning!

36.verse: You don’t want him to come suddenly and find you asleep.

37.verse: What I am telling you, I am telling everyone: keep watch!’

1.verse: Jesus Is Anointed at Bethany - Passover – the feast of unleavened bread – was due in two days. The chief priests and the lawyers were plotting how to seize Jesus by a trick, and kill him.

2.verse: ‘We can’t do it at the feast,’ they said. ‘The people might riot.’

3.verse: Jesus was in Bethany, at the house of Simon (known as ‘the Leper’). While he was at table, a woman came up with an alabaster pot containing extremely valuable ointment made of pure spikenard. She broke the pot and poured the ointment on Jesus’ head.

4.verse: Some of the people there grumbled to one another. ‘What’s the point of wasting the ointment?’ they asked.

5.verse: ‘That ointment could have been sold for three hundred dinars, and given to the poor.’ And they were angry with her.

6.verse: ‘Leave her alone,’ said Jesus. ‘Why make trouble for her? She has done a wonderful thing for me.

7.verse: You have the poor with you always; you can help them whenever you want to. But you won’t always have me.

8.verse: ‘She has played her part. She has anointed my body for its burial, ahead of time.

9.verse: I’m telling you the truth: wherever the message is announced in all the world, the story of what she has just done will be told. That will be her memorial.’

10.verse: Judas Iscariot, one of the Twelve, went to the chief priests, to arrange to hand Jesus over to them.

11.verse: They were delighted with his proposal, and made an agreement to pay him. And he began to look for a good moment to hand him over.

12.verse: The Last Supper - On the first day of unleavened bread, when the Passover lambs were sacrificed, Jesus’ disciples said to him, ‘Where would you like us to go and get things ready for you to eat the Passover?’

13.verse: He sent off two of his disciples, with these instructions. ‘Go into the city, and you will be met by a man carrying a water-pot. Follow him.

14.verse: When he goes indoors, say to the master of the house, “The teacher says, where is the guest room for me, where I can eat the Passover with my disciples?”

15.verse: He will show you a large upstairs room, set out and ready. Make preparations for us there.’

16.verse: The disciples went out, entered the city, and found it exactly as he had said. They prepared the Passover.

17.verse: When it was evening, Jesus came with the Twelve.

18.verse: As they were reclining at table and eating, Jesus said, ‘I’m telling you the truth: one of you is going to betray me – one of you that’s eating with me.’

19.verse: They began to be very upset, and they said to him, one after another, ‘It isn’t me, is it?’

20.verse: ‘It’s one of the Twelve,’ said Jesus, ‘one who has dipped his bread in the dish with me.

21.verse: Yes: the son of man is completing his journey, as scripture said he would; but it’s bad news for the man who betrays him! It would have been better for that man never to have been born.’

22.verse: While they were eating, he took bread, blessed it, broke it, and gave it to them. ‘Take it,’ he said. ‘This is my body.’

23.verse: Then he took the cup, gave thanks, and gave it to them, and they all drank from it.

24.verse: ‘This is my blood of the covenant,’ he said, ‘which is poured out for many.

25.verse: I’m telling you the truth: I won’t ever drink from the fruit of the vine again, until that day – the day when I drink it new in the kingdom of God.’

26.verse: Jesus Is Arrested - They sang a hymn, and went out to the Mount of Olives.

27.verse: ‘You’re all going to desert me,’ said Jesus, ‘because it’s written, I shall attack the shepherd and then the sheep will scatter.

28.verse: ‘But after I am raised up, I will go ahead of you to Galilee.’

29.verse: Peter spoke up. ‘Everyone else may desert you,’ he said, ‘but I won’t.’

30.verse: ‘I’m telling you the truth,’ Jesus replied. ‘Today – this very night, before the cock has crowed twice – you will renounce me three times.’

31.verse: This made Peter all the more vehement. ‘Even if I have to die with you,’ he said, ‘I will never renounce you.’ And all the rest said the same.

32.verse: They came to a place called Gethsemane. ‘Stay here’, said Jesus to the disciples, ‘while I pray.’

33.verse: He took Peter, James and John with him, and became quite overcome and deeply distressed.

34.verse: ‘ “My soul is disturbed within me”, he said, ‘right to the point of death. Stay here and keep watch.’

35.verse: He went a little further, and fell on the ground and prayed that, if possible, the moment might pass from him.

36.verse: ‘Abba, father,’ he said, ‘all things are possible for you! Take this cup away from me! But – not what I want, but what you want.’

37.verse: He returned and found them sleeping. ‘Are you asleep, Simon?’ he said to Peter. ‘Couldn’t you keep watch for a single hour?

38.verse: Watch and pray, so that you won’t come into the time of trouble. The spirit is eager, but the body is weak.’

39.verse: Once more he went off and prayed, saying the same words.

40.verse: And again, when he returned, he found them asleep, because their eyes were very heavy. They had no words to answer him.

41.verse: But the third time he came, he said to them, ‘All right – sleep as much as you like now. Have a good rest. The job is done, the time has come – and look! The son of man is betrayed into the clutches of sinners.

42.verse: Get up, let’s be on our way. Here comes the man who’s going to betray me.’

43.verse: At once, while he was still speaking, Judas, one of the Twelve, arrived, accompanied by a crowd, with swords and clubs, from the chief priests, the legal experts, and the elders.

44.verse: The betrayer had given them a coded sign: ‘The one I kiss – that’s him! Seize him and take him away safely.’

45.verse: He came up to Jesus at once. ‘Rabbi!’ he said, and kissed him.

46.verse: The crowd laid hands on him and seized him.

47.verse: One of the bystanders drew a sword and struck the high priest’s servant, cutting off his ear.

48.verse: Then Jesus spoke to them. ‘Anyone would think’, he said, ‘you’d come after a brigand! Fancy needing swords and clubs to arrest me!

49.verse: Day after day I’ve been teaching in the Temple, under your noses, and you never laid a finger on me. But the scriptures must be fulfilled.’

50.verse: Then they all abandoned him and ran away.

51.verse: A young man had followed him, wearing only a linen tunic over his otherwise naked body.

52.verse: They seized him, and he left the tunic and ran away naked.

53.verse: In the High Priest’s House - They took Jesus away to the high priest. All the chief priests and the elders and legal experts were assembled.

54.verse: Peter followed him at a distance, and came to the courtyard of the high priest’s house, where he sat with the servants and warmed himself at the fire.

55.verse: The chief priests, and all the Sanhedrin, looked for evidence for a capital charge against Jesus, but they didn’t find any.

56.verse: Several people invented fictitious charges against him, but their evidence didn’t agree.

57.verse: Then some stood up with this fabricated charge:

58.verse: ‘We heard him say, “I will destroy this Temple, which human hands have made, and in three days I’ll build another, made without human hands.” ’

59.verse: But even so their evidence didn’t agree.

60.verse: Then the high priest got up in front of them all and interrogated Jesus. ‘Haven’t you got any answer about whatever it is these people are testifying against you?’

61.verse: Jesus remained silent, and didn’t answer a word. Once more the high priest questioned him. ‘Are you the Messiah, the Son of the Blessed One?’

62.verse: ‘I am,’ replied Jesus, ‘and you will see “the son of man sitting at the right hand of Power, and coming with the clouds of heaven”.’

63.verse: ‘Why do we need any more evidence?’ shouted the high priest, tearing his clothes.

64.verse: ‘You heard the blasphemy! What’s your verdict?’ They all agreed on their judgment: he deserved to die.

65.verse: Some of them began to spit at him. They blindfolded him and hit him, and said, ‘Prophesy!’ And the servants took charge of him and beat him.

66.verse: Peter, meanwhile, was below in the courtyard. One of the high priest’s servant-girls came up

67.verse: and saw him warming himself. She looked closely at him, and said, ‘You were with Jesus the Nazarene too, weren’t you?’

68.verse: ‘I don’t know what on earth you’re talking about,’ replied Peter. He went outside into the forecourt, and the cock crowed.

69.verse: The servant-girl saw him, and once more began to say to the bystanders, ‘This man is one of them.’

70.verse: But Peter again denied it. A little while later the bystanders said again to Peter, ‘You really are one of them, aren’t you? You’re a Galilean!’

71.verse: At that he began to curse and swear, ‘I don’t know this man you’re talking about.’

72.verse: And immediately the cock crowed for the second time. Then Peter remembered the words that Jesus had said to him: ‘Before the cock crows twice, you will renounce me three times.’ And he burst into tears.

1.verse: Jesus Before Pilate - As soon as morning came, the chief priests held a council meeting with the elders, the legal experts, and the whole Sanhedrin. They bound Jesus, took him off to Pilate, and handed him over.

2.verse: ‘Are you the king of the Jews?’ asked Pilate. ‘You have said it,’ replied Jesus.

3.verse: The chief priests laid many accusations against him.

4.verse: Pilate again interrogated him: ‘Aren’t you going to make any reply? Look how many things they’re accusing you of!’

5.verse: But Jesus gave no reply at all, which astonished Pilate.

6.verse: The custom was that at festival time he used to release for them a single prisoner, whoever they would ask for.

7.verse: There was a man in prison named Barabbas, one of the revolutionaries who had committed murder during the uprising.

8.verse: So the crowd came up and began to ask Pilate to do what he normally did.

9.verse: ‘Do you want me’, answered Pilate, ‘to release for you “the king of the Jews”?’

10.verse: He said this because he knew that the chief priests had handed him over out of envy.

11.verse: The chief priests stirred up the crowd to ask for Barabbas instead to be released to them. So Pilate once again asked them,

12.verse: ‘What then do you want me to do with the one you call “the king of the Jews”?’

14.verse: ‘Why?’ asked Pilate. ‘What has he done wrong?’ ‘Crucify him!’ they shouted all the louder.

15.verse: Pilate wanted to satisfy the crowd; so he released Barabbas for them. He had Jesus flogged, and handed him over to be crucified.

16.verse: The Crucifixion - The soldiers took Jesus into the courtyard, that is, the Praetorium, and called together the whole squad.

17.verse: They dressed Jesus up in purple; then, weaving together a crown of thorns, they stuck it on him.

18.verse: They began to salute him: ‘Greetings, King of the Jews!’

19.verse: And they hit him over the head with a staff, and spat at him, and knelt down to do him homage.

20.verse: Then, when they had mocked him, they took the purple robe off him, and put his own clothes back on. Then they led him off to crucify him.

21.verse: They compelled a man called Simon to carry Jesus’ cross. He was from Cyrene, and was coming in from out of town. He was the father of Alexander and Rufus.

22.verse: They took Jesus to the place called Golgotha, which in translation means ‘Skull’s Place’.

23.verse: They gave him a mixture of wine and myrrh, but he didn’t drink it.

24.verse: So they crucified him; they ‘parted his clothing between them, casting lots’ to see who would get what.

25.verse: It was about nine o’clock in the morning when they crucified him.

26.verse: The inscription, giving the charge, read: ‘The King of the Jews’.

27.verse: They also crucified two bandits alongside him, one on his right and one on his left.

28.verse: verse doesn't exist in this bible version

29.verse: People who were passing by abused him. They shook their heads at him. ‘Hah!’ they said. ‘You were going to destroy the Temple, were you? And build it again in three days?

30.verse: Why don’t you rescue yourself, and come down from the cross?’

31.verse: The chief priests and the lawyers were mocking him in the same way among themselves. ‘He rescued others,’ they said, ‘but he can’t rescue himself.

32.verse: Messiah, is he? King of Israel, did he say? Well, let’s see him come down from the cross! We’ll believe him when we see that!’ The two who were crucified alongside him taunted him as well.

33.verse: The Death of Jesus - At midday there was darkness over all the land until three in the afternoon.

34.verse: At three o’clock Jesus shouted out in a powerful voice, ‘Eloi, Eloi, lema sabachthani?’ which means, ‘My God, my God, why did you abandon me?’

35.verse: When the bystanders heard it, some of them said, ‘He’s calling for Elijah!’

36.verse: One of them ran and filled a sponge with sour wine, put it on a pole, and gave it him to drink. ‘Well then,’ he declared, ‘let’s see if Elijah will come and take him down.’

37.verse: But Jesus, with another loud shout, breathed his last.

38.verse: The Temple veil was torn in two, from top to bottom.

39.verse: When the centurion who was standing facing him saw that he died in this way, he said, ‘This fellow really was God’s son.’

40.verse: The Burial of Jesus - Some women were watching from a distance. They included Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of the younger James and of Joses, and Salome.

41.verse: They had followed Jesus in Galilee, and had attended to his needs. There were several other women, too, who had come up with him to Jerusalem.

42.verse: It was already getting towards evening, and it was the day of Preparation, that is, the day before the sabbath.

43.verse: Joseph of Arimathea, a reputable member of the Council who was himself eagerly awaiting God’s kingdom, took his courage in both hands, went to Pilate, and requested the body of Jesus.

44.verse: Pilate was surprised that he was already dead. He summoned the centurion, and asked whether he had been dead for some time.

45.verse: When he learned the facts from the centurion, he conceded the body to Joseph.

46.verse: So Joseph bought a linen cloth, took the body down, wrapped it in the cloth, and laid it in a tomb cut out of the rock. He rolled a stone against the door of the tomb.

47.verse: Mary Magdalene and Mary the mother of Joses saw where he was buried.

1.verse: The Resurrection - When the sabbath was over, Mary Magdalene, Mary the mother of James, and Salome bought spices so that they could come and anoint Jesus.

2.verse: Then, very early on the first day of the week, they came to the tomb, just at sunrise.

3.verse: They were saying to one another, ‘There’s that stone at the door of the tomb – who’s going to roll it away for us?’

4.verse: Then, when they looked up, they saw that it had been rolled away. (It was extremely large.)

5.verse: So they went into the tomb, and there they saw a young man sitting on the right-hand side. He was wearing white. They were totally astonished.

6.verse: ‘Don’t be astonished,’ he said to them. ‘You’re looking for Jesus the Nazarene, who was crucified. He has been raised! He isn’t here! Look – this is the place where they laid him.

7.verse: ‘But go and tell his disciples – including Peter – that he is going ahead of you to Galilee. You’ll see him there, just like he told you.’

8.verse: They went out, and fled from the tomb. Trembling and panic had seized them. They said nothing to anyone, because they were afraid.

9.verse: Two Extra Endings - [[They gave a brief account to the people around Peter of what they had been told. After this, Jesus himself sent out from East to West, through their work, the sacred and imperishable proclamation of eternal salvation. Amen.]] [When Jesus was raised, early on the first day of the week, he appeared first of all to Mary Magdalene, from whom he had cast out seven demons.

10.verse: She went and told the people who had been with him, who were mourning and weeping.

11.verse: When they heard that he was alive, and that he had been seen by her, they didn’t believe it.

12.verse: After this he appeared in a different guise to two of them as they were walking into the countryside.

13.verse: They came back and told the others, but they didn’t believe them.

14.verse: Later Jesus appeared to the eleven themselves, as they were at table. He told them off for their unbelief and hardheartedness, for not believing those who had seen him after he had been raised.

15.verse: ‘Go into all the world,’ he said to them, ‘and announce the message to all creation.

16.verse: Anyone who believes and is baptized will be rescued, but people who don’t believe will be condemned.

17.verse: And these signs will happen around those who believe: they will drive out demons in my name, they will speak with new tongues,

18.verse: they will pick up serpents in their hands; and if they drink anything poisonous it won’t harm them. They will lay their hands on the sick, and they will get better.’

19.verse: When the Lord Jesus had spoken with them, he was taken up into heaven, and sat down at God’s right hand.

20.verse: They went out and announced the message everywhere. The Lord worked with them, validating their message by the signs that accompanied them.]
